_header: Wherefore pray we to him to make us steadfast in our fay
_description: On St Thomas the Apostle’s proving our faith, in Mirk’s Festial — two couplets

BodGoughet4.Editions:
Erbe,  Theodore,
                        ed.  
             Mirk’s Festial.
EETS
         e.s. 96 (1905); repr. 1987: 20-1.
Sisam,  Celia,  and  Kenneth Sisam, eds.  
             The Oxford Book of Medieval English Verse.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1970: 373-4.

CULDd1050.Transcription:
Thus preuyd he owre feythe & did wondres in hes weyand grete
                    miracles on his dayþer for worchepe we hym þat he meymake vs
                    stedfaste in owre feythe & helpe vs in owre long weyAnd brynge vs
                    þedur as ys no nyȝt but euerlastyng day
CULDd1050.Note:
With two preceding lines that also have same rhyme, though of irregular
                    length.

BLCottClauAII.Transcription:
He doth al so mony wondrus on hys dayfor alle þe contre cometh
                    þedur on hys day& takn hosul of þat hond in þis
                    wyseþe byschep of þat cyte synguth þe masse þat
                    day

BLHar2403.Transcription:
þus he preveth our feith & did wondres in his wey& grete
                    myracles on his dayWherefor pray we hym make vs sted faste in our feith
                    & help vs in our long wey& þeras is no nyght but euerlasty
                    day

BLHar2417.Transcription:
Þus he preued owr faþ and dude grete wondres in his
                    way& doth grete myrakeles on his dayAnd þerfore praye we hym
                    to make vs stedefaste in owr feyth& to helpe vs in owr long wayand
                    brynge vs þyder as ys noo nyȝt but euerlastyng day

Southwell7.Transcription:
Thus he provyd oure feyth and dyd wondrys in his weyand grete
                    myraclis aftyre his deth one his dayWherfore pray we to hym to make vs
                    stedefast in oure feyth and helpe vs in oure longe weyand bryng vs
                    þedyre as ye neuer nyȝt but euer day
Southwell7.Note:
With two preceding lines that also have same rhyme, though of irregular
                    length; ends in prose, ‘that ys to sey to euerlastyng ioy to the which
                    & cetera’.
